TL:DR? See ConclusionNOTE: I originally finished the game using my disc based copy of the game bought in 2007. I bought it again on steam because it was included in the Crysis Franchise Pack.INTRODUCTION:One of the rare PC Exclusive titles to break free from the Console's restrictive and dated hardware. Crysis 1 was the benchmark for most PC games back in 2007 until it was finally replaced by Metro 2033 in 2010.Crysis follows the story of Jake "Nomad" Dunn, member of a Delta Ops Nano Team tasked with infiltrating an Island currently occupied by North Korean Forces. Not soon after landing, the Delta team finds out that the KPA is the least of their worries.PROS:+ Cutting Edge Graphics: -Considering this game was released in 2007, Crysis can still go toe-to-toe with the 2012 game Far Cry 3. Back then, almost 95% of all PCs in the world could not run Crysis on its maximum settings. Crysis 1 was meant to be a PC only exclusive mostly because the developers really wanted to push both their creative freedom and raw hardware power. This is the game also spawned the internet meme: "But can it run Crysis?"+ Innovative Gameplay: -This game was the first to introduce the Nano Suit which added a wide variety of new approaches to missions and objectives. A Quick hand and good reflexes are needed to fully utilize the Nano Suit's power.+ Pseudo Open World: -Its not Sandbox, but it's not linear. Each mission objective involves a map of gigantic proportions where you can go and carefully plan out your strategy before going in a mission. Like what I said in my SW: Republic Commando Review, not every game needs to be sandbox. Crysis 1 had a good style by giving enough freedom while keeping the player in a directed flow in the story.CONS:- Terrible Optimization: -Although it was the Graphical Flagship of its time, the devs mainly focused on sheer brute force power of the GPU but made so little optimization. If properly optimized, most mid-range PCs could have ran this game a bit better.- Unresolved Bugs: -6 years and some of the bugs from the first release still persists. Downloading some of the latest patches actually causes a bug. Not game breaking but terribly annoying.- Resolution Problem: -You may or may not encounter this problem but the game seems to have a problem doing a full screen with a 1920x1080 resolution. To fix this, you'll need to edit the settings via note pad.CONCLUSION:MUST HAVE. One of the landmark games that dared a primarily Console dominated market to shine a great light once more to the PC.Additional Note: This is not a fast paced action game like COD or Battlefield. This game actually requires some planning and tactical movements to get the job done, specially in some of the harder difficulties.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------Like my Reviews? 												This game is well-known for being beautiful, but to desribe it only as eye candy really sells Crysis short.  There's a lot to enjoy about the gameplay, especially how it breaks up the old "series of chest-high-walls" shooter formula.As a super soldier your suit contains a variety of powers that can be toggled between:  super strength (enhancing melee abilities), super speed, maximum armor, and active camouflage (which makes you truly invisible to enemies who haven't seen you yet).  Active camo is the true selling point, learning to use it (and honestly, abuse it) is what keeps you alive.  Your character is not well suited for going in guns blazing, you'll rely on stealth and run-and-gun tactics against enemies who prefer to hunt you instead of bunkering down behind a chest high wall.  In general, human enemy AI is fantastic and pushes you to quickly learn how to survive a Crysis fire-fight.Weapons customization is another well-done aspect of Crysis.  The same gun can be customized to a short/medium range spray-and-pray style semi-automatic, or a long-range silenced sniper with a scope and laser sight, all pretty much on-the-fly.  So while the number of unique weapons is actually pretty small (5 or 6 maybe), you can get a lot more mileage out of them through customization.  While the first stretch of the game fighting human enemies is very fun, the game has an abrupt change when you begin to encounter mostly aliens.  I definitely found this part much less enjoyable, it seems more about showing what you can do with the Cry Engine than keeping the game fun for the player.  My level of interest dropped off pretty sharply, to the extent that I didn't even finish the game.That doesn't mean I'm not glad I bought it (I definitely still recommened it), and you may not have the same experience I had.

												It took me a while to be fond of this game as I played it years ago and while my rig met the minimum requirements (almost reached the recommended ones) it had a hard time running Crysis on it properly. There were numerous glitches, audio issues and frequent CTDs.But you know what? Putting the technical difficulties aside this is a damn fine game! You play Nomad, a special forces soldier who wears a so-called nanosuit. The story takes place in the future and the objective is to find out what happened on the island previously seized by Koreans. While you traverse through the deep jungle and small settlements you notice two things: the game is stunningly beautiful (there was a reason for the high system reqs) and that by hiding-shooting you cannot eliminate your foes. You need to utilise your nanosuit. You can bring up a special menu and select from various abilities. Speed makes you faster, Strength allows you to melee your foes or throw bigger objects and Stealth makes you invisible. All drain your energy bar (which will refill automatically, but slowly) and I do not have to mention that Stealth is the most exciting and most useful among all. Oh, yes, there's a 4th power enabling you to take more damage.Enemy AI is great - they respond to the noises, work in squads and will try to find you even if you are invisible. On greater difficulty settings they speak Korean so you do not understand what commands they give to one another.Occasionally, the game throws in some scripted cutscenes - these look good and also interesting. By looking at the pictures on the store page one can guess what they'll find (and what the army was really looking into), but let's not spoil it here.Crysis is a stunningly beautiful game (even today considering it's more than 5 years old) and makes for an interesting, action-packed ride.WARNING: This review is based on playing the game on a 32-bit operating system. As per the feedbacks on the store page and amongst the discussions people detail further issues when it comes to 64-bit systems. I understand there is a workaround which has been tried and found good, still, this is just to let you know that before the purchase you should look into this.

												Crysis is a  first-person shooter game developed by Crytek and published by Electronic Arts in 2007.An elite group travels to North Korea to investigate an artifact. While the player faces Korean soldiers and research facilities , an alien ship prepares to emerge and begin the invasion of Earth . Nomad  faces Korean forces and tries to defeat the alien threat . The game submerges us under incredibly detailed rainforests. The physics of the game is excellent . Apart from the story, one enjoys walking around the environment , breaking the palms, catching animals, piloting boats , swimming with fish , and driving around the islands.The graphics engine is the successor to Far Cry . It was a real revolution in real-time graphics . The image quality and texture is still among the best of all time . This makes the game very immersive . It took five years after release to play the game with very high quality settings and get  a reasonable experience. Many people spoke at the time of bad optimization when in fact the game has three times more polygons than his contemporaries , volumetric clouds , day- night phases and huge maps. Nothing compared to the fixed pixelated sky on a Call of Duty game .The player has a special suit that gives different powers or abilities for a period of time, such as invisibility , speed or armor. While it is not a Sandbox, it has  open maps that simulate the world much better than its very linear successor, Crysis 2. In that regard, it is even better than Crysis 3.The game was one of the best action games of 2007 but did not have many sales due to high specifications, hardware requirements and DirectX 10. It has two Secuels . Crysis 2 and Crysis 3 .While Crysis 3 surpasses some of its graphic , 1 remains the best game of the 3 .The game was released for Windows PC , PS3 and XBOX 360 before being ported to MAC OSX.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ESPAÑOL--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Crysis es un videojuego de disparos en primera persona desarrollado por Crytek y distribuido por Electronic Arts en 2007.Un grupo de elite viaja a Corea del Norte a investigar un artefacto. Mientras que el jugador se enfrenta a soldados coreanos e investiga instalaciones, una nave alienígena se prepara para emerger y comenzar la invasión de la tierra. Jake Nomad deberá enfrentarse a las fuerzas coreanas y alienígneas para intentar derrotarlas. El juego nos lleva por selvas tropicales increiblemente detalladas. La física del juego es excelente. Al margen de la historia uno disfruta de pasear por el entorno, romper las palmeras, agarrar animales, pilotar lanchas, nadar con peces y manejar vehículos por las islas. El motor gráfico es el sucesor del Far Cry. Fue una verdadera revolución en cuanto a gráficos en tiempo real. La calidad de imagen y texturas sigue estando entre las mejores de todos los tiempos. Esto hace al juego muy inmersivo. Recién después de cinco años pudo jugarse el juego con la calidad máxima activada y una experiencia razonable. Mucha gente habló en su momento de mala optimización cuando en realidad el juego tenia tres veces mas polígonos que sus contemporaneos, nubes volumétricas, fases dia - noche y mapas enormes. Nada que ver con el cielo pixelado y fijo de un Call of Duty. El jugador posee un traje especial que le confiere poderes especiales por un lapso de tiempo, como la invisibilidad, la velocidad o armadura. Si bien no es un Sandbox posee mapas que simulan un mundo abierto mucho mejor que su muy lineal sucesor, el Crysis 2.El juego fue uno de los mejores juegos de acción de 2007 aunque no tuvo muchas ventas debido a las altas especificaciones y el requerimiento de DirectX 10 para aprovecharlo al máximo. Posee dos seculas. El Crysis 2 y el Crysis 3. Si bien el Crysis 3 lo supera en algunos de sus aspectos gráficos, el 1 sigue siendo el mejor de los 3. El juego se lanzó para PC bajo Windows, PS3 y XBOX 360 para luego ser portado a MAC OSX.

And also I think it makes for some very fun options gameplay wise. You have great mobility with speed and strength mode. you can choose to fight as a tank with armor mode (although you still die very quick on delta difficulty so its not crazy overpowered) and you can play very stealthy with the cloak mode (which makes you almost but not completly invisible).All those abilities use the suit's energy, so they can not be used indefinitly.And the best thing is you can switch in between the diffrent suitmodes at any time, so you can adapt your playstyle to the situation at any given time.Last: The Multiplayer:So appereantly the multiplayer doesn't work anymore due to the service it used (gamespy) shutting down. And I'd recommend it to anyone who hasn't played it yet. (9/10) (10/10 if you choose to ignore the slightly weaker story)

												Warning, contains mild (Edit: heavy) spoilers.Never having played the famous Crysis, I thought I'd finally give it a shot and find out what the fuss is all about. Naturally, since I played this in 2014, my perspective on the game will be very different from the one who played it when it came out. But only an hour into the game, I realized why people call it such a revolutionary shooter for its time. I didn't play with any mods, yet I would've never guessed the game I was playing came out in 2007 judging from what it presented to me. This is due to the following reasons:- The vastness of the world and the graphical fidelity are overwhelmingly impressive for an FPS title this old. You can clearly see that the CryEngine is designed to push the limits on what's possible in terms of looks and scope. I was impressed by how open-world-y the terrain is, yet the missions are unmistakably straightforward... which turns out to be an incredibly fun combination in my opinion. Being dropped on a tropical island where you shoot people in a vast and open area offering multiple ways of approaching your goals is to my mind a great way to design an FPS. The level of detail is stunning to say the least for a 2007 title, I have seen much worse in considerably newer titles.- The gunplay, gun variety and AI are simply great. Shooting enemies feels fun, feels rewarding and feels challenging since the AI actively tries to hunt you down when you for example sneaked away again using cloak. One of the core mechanics, the exosuit and its accompanying suit powers offer great variety for both people who like to be stealthy or those who love to cause mayhem. I found a mix of these to be the most effective and entertaining. ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥it I think I never experienced as much satisfaction as when I blew up a truck with a rocket launcher while crouching in a bush with cloak engaged. The effects are mindblowing, as are the sound assets, just really immersive overall.- Performance is solid. With CFX 7950/7970 I easily manage 60fps, except for very intense scenes involving lots of explosions and stuff. FoV seems to be exceptionally high, I didn't see a slider for it in the menu, but it's at least 100 by default, which is great. Sadly there's a few bugs involving for example scripted events and cutscenes not triggering correctly when loading from quicksaves amidst a level, nothing game-breaking though. Also, 1920x1080 or higher resolution is not enabled by default, you have to manually adjust it in the config file, which is no big deal though.- The level design is interesting enough. While most levels feature open tropical island terrain with hilly, foresty areas, there's also a sequence where you are in weightless space, floating around inside a gigantic alien structure; very impressive and intriguing overall. The enemy variety is great too: From your usual infantry of all kind to jeeps, tanks, helicopters, boats to rather pesky flying alien crystalline squids with fast-firing energy weapons to a huge♥♥♥♥♥alien motherfugger in the process of sinking a motherfuggin aircraft carrier. It should be noted that you can drive jeeps, tanks, boats and helicopters yourself which is super fun if you like to shoot up stuff in the most classy way imaginable.Negative points? I have one major one, but perhaps it's not really valid since the game clearly doesn't focus on that aspect at all and never pretends to:The story is mindblowingly clichée and superficial: >Technologically augmented super soldier infiltrates fictional island under the control of evil North Koreans, gathers intel, blows up stuff, uncovers archeological project gone overboard, sleeping alien entity that feeds itself off energy awakens, causes major destruction, gruffy American general wants to drop nuke on island to kill off the monstrosity, super-intelligent scientists who always know it better advise against it, alien gets nuked anyway, becomes massively stronger, protagonist has to beat XXL format version of alien monstrosity using lots of missiles and a super secret prototype weapon which had never been field-tested but works like a charm (why wouldn't it?), escapes a sinking aircraft carrier and goes right back into the fight because he's a badass and a superhuman, dutiful soldier-tough-guy who has no fear and throughout the entire game requires no sleep at all. There, that's the plot in a nutshell for you. Not really intentended in the beginning but hey, these are spontaneous and minimally structured reviews after all so w/e. So there you go, awesome FPS, don't play it for the story, play it for the mechanics and the looks. This is how every modern military shooter should be. You can make a very linear, bland narrative without sacrificing diversity and creativity in terms of gameplay and mechanics. Crysis taught us this. No score here, read the damn review if you care for my opinion on it.

												Do you miss first person action games like GoldenEye, Thief 2, and the original Ghost Recon? If you miss games that simply put you in an environment, gave you some objectives, and let you figure out how to do them without driving you down a rollercoaster, the original Crysis is arguably the last and most technically advanced game of this type to be developed. The visual achievements of the CryEngine have overshadowed the fact that this game, well most of it at least, is a shining example of objective-based game design released just before everyone took shooters in the complete opposite direction.The first level, which is shown off in the demo that’s available at crysisdemo.com as of this writing, is a perfect example of this. In a small bay occupied by a few enemy fortifications along the shore and some motorboat patrols, Crysis gives you two main objectives and an optional objective to tackle in any order. You can work your way along the coastline through the forts, take over a boat to zip around the bay, or whatever, through any combination of stealth and assault tactics.This continues through the next several levels which are sort of a linear chain of small sandboxes: a village you can infiltrate from multiple angles, a group of bases along a river, a harbor, and so-on. The level design in all these areas is quite good, always giving you options and setups for fire fights that never happen the same way twice. This is even true in the game’s more linear sections early on. In the early parts (more on that later), even when Crysis is a corridor it’s still a very wide corridor.I think the best way to describe the core game mechanics would be to call Crysis a simulation based on the original 1987 Predator movie. Your tools are Schwarzenegger-esque explosions and futuristic super powers. The nanosuit let’s you choose between super armor (the default), increased running speed, and a temporary stealth cloak. You’ll probably use the cloak the most but the other powers offer potential for fun combinations and interesting choices. Super strength let’s you jump higher, and you can combine it with speed for running super jumps. When sniping you can choose between staying hidden with the cloak or using strength for a more stable shooting arm.Behind the nanosuit the Crysis boasts a varied sandbox of shooter mechanics. Not only is there the ever-present option of stealth, but you can also lift and throw most objects at enemies and control various vehicles. Most buildings in the game are also dynamically destructible through the physics engine, which feels like it has a tangible effect on gameplay. Crysis even let’s you fit most weapons with a modest variety of attachments with a quick tap of the C key like different sights or a silencer.The reason you might hear a lot of people praise Crysis by saying “the first half” or “the first two thirds” of the game, is because for some reason it turns into a different, much worse game at a specific point later on. The later sections of Crysis are far more linear and introduce gameplay mechanics that while unique, just don’t work that well.  It’s probably best if you stop playing when you start a boss fight with a North Korean general. The most succinct thing I can say is at that point it feels like the level designers ran out of gas.The good parts of Crysis though will still net you at least around 10 hours of gameplay, and that’s just for one run. I consider Crysis to be a pretty replayable game just because you can approach its missions with multiple strategies, but also because each difficulty mode above normal changes things considerably.On normal you can pretty much toy with enemies using the nanosuit. On hard you can still play with them a little bit, but you have to be smart about it. Higher difficulties change a few core mechanics, and the deadlier enemies ensure you have to rethink the way you use the cloak and cover. Hard and Delta mode almost turn Crysis into a straight-up stealth game.Of course what Crysis is most well-known for is the “but can it run Crysis?” joke pertaining to the game’s harsh treatment of processors. Even after six years, Crysis is not an extremely easy game to run. My GTX 760 still only get’s 60 frames per second MOST of the time in 1080p. The consumer experience when you first install the game doesn’t make things easier either.Being from the early days of DirectX 10, Crysis forces it on you by artificially locking the highest graphics features behind DX10 when they are in fact available on DX9 just by editing the ini file or downloading a custom one. DX10 does little more than drag down performance of the already demanding Crysis.If you’re wondering if Crysis still holds up visually after six years, I think with vanilla settings it’s beginning to show its age, but still looks significantly better than most console games released in even the last couple years. Really, only the highest-end recent PC games (Crysis 3, Metro, Battlefield 4), and next-gen-console-only launch games like Killzone Shadow Fall beat it. It can still look impressive with custom ini files and texture packs though.I think it’s kind of a crime Crysis got labled as just “that really pretty PC game nobody can run.” In my opinion it’s one of the most underrated first person shooters of this past console generation (it did come out on consoles eventually after all), if not one of the best. It’s one of the last, if not the last of a breed of shooter that game designers seemingly forgot in the chase after Call of Duty’s popularity.

Teal DeerDevelopers: CrytekPublishers: Electronic ArtsInitial release: Nov 2007Genre: FPS#Worth/NotWorth: #SoWorthExposition, Concurrence and SummationWhoever said this was a glorified tech demo had their head buried in a hole.Crysis is a truly open world first person shooter. Nothing before nor after (at least at the time of writing this) has matched its prowess of being able to almost literally do anything you can think of to complete a task or objective. You're given an experimental special ops nanosuit. A suit that has the ability to infuse strength, provide protection, increase speed as well as provide a stealth cloak. Limited only by the suits energy levels, these functions can be swapped on the fly. Aside from the suit you have a extremely modifiable weapon not to mention weapon pick ups that are additionally modifiable; from silencers, stocks, sights and auto/semi fire type can be exchanged at a whims notice. As well as vehicles and gun mounts to use, any play-style is immediately within your grasp. There is nothing quite like punching through a wall and blasting the occupants close range with a shotgun with full armor going “H.A.M.” and tanking it. With the dichotomy of attaching a scope, applying strength to steady scope sway and using a silencer to drop enemies from afar and then go in closer using your cloak and take them out with a pistol or however else you may desire. With all of these options at the ready constantly, you are truly only limited by your suits given power at the moment, your imagination and I suppose the edge of the map if you want to be that guy. The StoryIt's not going to win any awards, its certainly a big blockbuster summer movie thriller. But its got that primal visceral gumption to effectively pull at your heart strings and asks you to defend humanity from certain doom and annihilation during an alien invasion. A very, very minor spoiler warning; There are some very well done sequences involving the loss of power and the absence of heat that will really test your resourcefulness of the games mechanics. THE GISTOne of my favorite all time first person shooters that doesn't deserve the negative assertion of it being a tech demo it receive during the time of its initial release. It is far more than that and is still a lot better than some of the more modern shooters I've seen.Follow my curation for more

~Maximum Review~This Action-FPS game was released back in November, 2007. But at the time it had some of the best graphics ever for a game of its kind! The main reason behind this was the kickass-German made Crytek engine that used a heavy demand on graphics cards at the time to present lots of new features. Does crytek sound familiar at all? if it does-that is because they also created the first far cry game waay back in 2004! 


Crysis 
A Screenshot of Crysis
By: Jaeger




These kinds of games typically have big expanses of various maps and consists of stealth missions near the start and middle sections but blooms into a beautiful action-set experience with lots of options! (Even some optional quests!). Crysis was no different and delivered a great action game with many new useful features/gameplay mechanics that more than made up for simpified story sequences, crappy nano-suit power (It is the damn future!) and some really dumb AI.Anyway i dont want to list everything this game offers here! instead ill chop it into clean little pieces and serve you....The Pros and Cons.Pros:+SO many awesome small little additions to gameplay that make a big difference! Some of these include: Your PC's battery level shown, lots more graphics and weapon options at the time, Minimap accuracy with coordinates,  enhanced physics and a deadly shark to stop people from leaving the map! A frickin shark!!+I really liked the Abilities FOR the nanosuit, but not the Nanosuit itself (Because of numerous energy reasons that ill describe in Cons below) The Cloak, Speed and Strength are used regularly, and for good reason!+The Story is very strong and warhead fits in very well. The Title really fits the plot! and the "Futuristic spelling" helps a little bit too i guess. No Purposeful emotional scenes or anything  like that, its an action game dammit! Shoot Cephs first and ask questions later!.But the story has got some great seperation between the stealth and action sequences! A calm cutscene to recap what big event just occured, followed by a guerilla-style trespass on an enemy base is a great mix! Basicsally what im trying to say is that the Pacing in this game is very well done. +The Vehicles some of which include: A tank, a Vtol jet, a Military jeep and military dinghyhandle very well surprisingly and are easy to control, speaking of that...+The tutorial is hardly a tuturial and just a slow part of the story that just happens to teach you the controls. Which are simple and very easy to change! Despite these abilities, the player still has to choose his actions with care, for exposing himself to multiple enemies can still mean a quick death.  Due to this, the game remains challenging throughout the course of the adventure.The mission design is rich in diversity: apart from on-foot sections, the player is often able to use enemy trucks and boats to traverse the large playing areas, and may even pilot tanks and a VTOL aircraft over the course of the single player campaign.Unfortunately the game drops off towards its slightly unsatisfying conclusion, as it trades in its sandbox gameplay for more linear level design.Overall Crysis was a very fun experience due to the freedom given to the player and the options given by the Nanosuit. CrysisBack when this game was first released, I remember how my PC at the time refused to even start it. Once I finally upgraded, I spent quite a few hours playing the demo, but I never ended up purchasing the full game. I noticed it on a Steam sale one day, and decided I'd finally finish the first-person shooter that gave me so many options, even with only one level.GraphicsWhen Crysis was first released, it was groundbreaking. It pushed every graphical limit known at the time, and the result was one of the most detailed and greatest looking first-person shooter games ever created. Post processing was used tastefully, almost every part of the environment is on the same high level of detail, and though some newer games have since left it in the dust, Crysis still holds up nicely, showing up games like Far Cry 3 or Arma 3 Apex thanks to the beautifully crafted levels of the Ling Shan islands. The only faults that Crysis has in the graphical department pertain to two vastly different ends of the spectrum. Terrain detail suffers the closer you get to the map boundaries, and character models - more specifically, face models - could definitely be better. With that said, if you want something nice to look at, Crysis will still give you that.


Crysis 
A Screenshot of Crysis
By: MorGun




AudioAudio design in Crysis is similarly high quality on most fronts. Weapons all sound punchy and satisfying, and the environmental effects are fantastic. The soundtrack, while not especially noteworthy, does contain some very nice orchestral tracks, and the game was scored well. The only major flaw with audio design is the voice acting and writing. The writing itself was like something out of a B-movie, and the voice acting quality matched it accordingly. One nice consolation about the voice acting is that all KPA troops will speak Korean on the highest difficulty level.PerformanceWhen this game was first released, it was often criticized for its performance. The question in many people's minds about PC gaming became, "Can it run Crysis? and often times, the answer would be no. But thankfully, as hardware has evolved, most people will have little trouble running this game now. My system runs Crysis on maximum settings and maintains a nice 60 frames per second at almost all times. There aren't many bugs that I've found, and although I did encounter a handful during my play-through, none of them were game-breaking.GameplayAt first glance, Crysis probably looks like a run-of-the-mill first-person shooter. Taking a deeper look reveals, however, what makes it so unique. The player is equipped with an experimental Nanosuit, a wonderful piece of technology that allows for them to switch into different enhanced modes: Maximum strength, speed, armor, or a cloaking system. This allows for situations to be tackled in almost any way imaginable, with either a focus on stealth and guerrilla tactics or pure shock and awe. There is also an on-the-fly weapon customization system, allowing the player to swap out attachments on every weapon to suit whatever situation they're faced with. This all leads to an immense amount of freedom in both single- and multiplayer environments, and is one of the things that makes Crysis so fun to play.


Crysis 
A Screenshot of Crysis
By: Vagabund




SingleplayerThe singleplayer campaign of Crysis places the player into the boots of Jake Dunn, a member of the futuristic Delta Force team Raptor, assigned to the Ling Shan islands in the Philippines. Raptor team was sent to locate an archaeologist who was taken hostage by task force of the Korean People's Army, though they soon discover there are far deadlier things at play than just the KPA forces on the ground. Each level is sequential and allows the player to carry over their items from the last, and each one presents the player with one goal or another, typically miles away from where they start. This means that the player is free to reach their objective however they want; some might opt to steal a vehicle and blast through KPA checkpoints, while others might stealthily creep through the jungle undetected. There are eleven levels in the campaign, each taking place in a different part of the islands, and the campaign itself will take most players between eight and twelve hours to complete, depending on the difficulty level and their tactics.MultiplayerThe multiplayer component of Crysis featured two primary gamemodes; Power Struggle and Instant Action. The latter was a run-of-the-mill deathmatch gamemode, made more unique by equipping every player with Nanosuits. The more unique and popular gamemode was Power Struggle, which at first glance resembled Conquest from the Battlefield series. The biggest divergence from Conquest was how a team would win; a specialized 'TAC' heavy tank would have to fire a tactical nuclear warhead at the other team's main base, obliterating it. Larger maps also featured factories in addition to normal objectives, which would produce vehicles over time, rather than simply spawning vehicles when an objective was controlled like in Battlefield. Unfortunately, I describe all of this in the past tense because the multiplayer was run through GameSpy, and Crysis did not receive a multiplayer patch after GameSpy shut down. As a result, there is, to my knowledge, no multiplayer community left in Crysis.


Crysis 
A Screenshot of Crysis
By: Stan




Community ContentCrysis redeems itself for its lackluster multiplayer component here. It features a terrain editor known as Sandbox which allows for the creation of both single- and multiplayer maps, and also supports user modifications. These modifications are unfortunately (mostly) limited to new weapons and vehicles, but you'll still probably be able to get a few more hours out of Crysis thanks to its support for community content.VerdictThe Crysis franchise is a bit of a tragic tale in my mind. The first game was so unique, and yet its developers threw away nearly all of what made it unique in favor of two scripted corridor shooter sequels which are, if you will, "all looks and no brains." Crysis certainly isn't a thinking man's game like the Arma series can be, but if you're looking an interesting and entertaining semi-open world first-person shooter and you see Crysis on sale, I would definitely endorse it.I would recommend Crysis, but would suggest waiting for a sale.

												Now, don't let the age or tacky trailers fool you; Crysis, 9 years later, is still a phenomenal game that sent the industry forward. Imagine an FPS that removed most of the stupid cliches of modern FPS games, getting rid of things like "shotguns are short range" and "melee attacks deal 100x damage". When I first hopped into the game, I expected an FPS I would play for 3~ hours and say "eh, it was worth 4 dollars". What I got was a unique experience that left me with a constant desire to replay the game again and again,GAMEPLAY:Playing a tad like Far Cry (The developers started the series, featuring huge environment and gameplay similarities) or modern MGS, it allows you to approach enemies with a variety of ways with an INSANE ammount of ways to approach it. It isn't like Dishonored (Which I also highly reccomend) where every option feels forced and in your face; I can switch to Strength mode and knock down a hut, then use the curved roof as a ramp to launch myself out of danger by charging at it in speed mode. Encounter a 3 man patrol? pick up the strongest of the group, switch to strength mode, snap his neck and then toss him at another soldier, before finishing off the last one with a bullet to the head or a punch strong enough to instantly incapitate him. Base surrounded by trip mines? single individual guards out, toss them over the wall, and walk away as his body slides over the mines. Cornered by 4 men and using a box as cover? Switch to Strength mode, smash the box with the butt of a shotgun, then have the now flying box incapitate them all. Small radio station on a hill? lure the opposition into a frail building then smash the roof, causing the building to collapse and kill everyone inside. Taking the high ground to scout is beneficial, as in one situation I spotted a car 'bout half a mile off speeding down the road, allowing me to take the chance to shoot out its tires from a long distance, causing the speeding vehicle to go spiraling into a ditch, killing the crew inside. While scouting, I spotted an attack boat surverying a cargo loading zone. As the boat went further down shore, I dove to the bottom of the seabed. As the boat made its approach, I switched to speed mode and swam upward at superhuman speed, sending me a good 20~ feet out of the water... and allowing me to toss a grenade stright into the boat. Armored patrol of 5 getting out of a car? Strength mode, jump to one side, kill the two koreans and shoot the gunner atop the car, then punch the car hard enough to send it spiraling into the remaining Koreans. Catch a DISGUSTING COMMUNIST taking a leak (Enemies actually do this) at a river? hold him underwater until he drowns.Needless to say, the game is packed with variety, and even without it, the gunplay, which is phenomenally realistic and enjoyable, would alone make the game worth it.STORY:A bit generic on the outside (Crysis 2 and 3 aren't as good but expanded on the story quite well), Crysis' story is quite good, but certainly not the best feature of the game. SPOILERS AHEAD; Technologically advanced Aliens nicknamed the Ceph are advanced to the point of being able to create anything they can think of; so, they turn their minds to things they cannot think of or predict. They send "Colonization pods" to planets that have the potential to host life, with our world being Pod-ed two-million years before Humanity came to exist. In 1912, Richard Hargreave sets out on an expedition with 3 other individuals to Alaska, where there is rumored "riches". What he and his crew discover, however, is a massive ammount of Ceph Technology. Hargreave's two colleagues are heavily injured in the operation, and using alien tech, he saves their lives with reported super-human abilities. Hargreave, being a genius, founds Hargreave Science Corp, and begins to use Ceph technology to create weapontry and amass a fortune. Sometime between 1990 and 2200, Hargreave begins to fear a Ceph awakening and allies Hargreave Science Corp. and the child company Crynet Systems (Hence why "Crysis" is spelt the way it is) with the United States, giving them acess to Nano-Suit technology.  North Korea discovers and alien colonization pod on the Lang Shian Islands and mobilizes the North Korean People's Army to evacuate the island with the intention of utilizing Alien technology to become most advanced civilization and to defeat the United States. However, their intentions are never fufilled, as two elite Nanosuit teams (Team Raptor, Crysis 1, and Team Eagle, Crysis Warhead) defeat massive ammounts of Korean People Army Forces, and combined with the awakening of the Ceph colonization pod, which the main charecter of Crysis 1, Nomad, enters in an attempt to defeat the Ceph. Realizing his efforts are futile, he attempts to escape the pod, only to be met with a Frozen Wasteland created by the Ceph in an attempt to push out human forces. Nomad, Psycho, and Prophet (Nanosuited Individuals) escape the frozen landscape and rejoin eachother on a U.S Battleship, where Nomad is provided an experimental tactical nuke device, and also where the Captain of the ship fails to realize that Ceph absorb energy, foolishly launching a massive nuclear missle into the massive, frozen dome, causing it to massively expand and to trigger the full force of the Ceph invasion. The Ceph assault the ship, and after defeating a massive alien monster called "The Hunter", the ship is attacked by a gigantic alien battleship, witch sinks the ship and is barely defeated by Nomad. This "Victory" is only a small one in a massive war, with more to come in Crysis 2 and 3 (Honestly, just read about the lore. The games are pretty bad and ruined any chance of the series being any good once more)I hope you've enjoyed my lengthy review. Crysis is easily one of my favorite games of all time, if not THE favorite (Next to New Vegas <3). I'm sure you'll enjoy the game, here are some mods I reccomend;Blackfire's Mod Ultimate OR CyberAlien's Extreme Immersive modAdvanced AIRealistic EnhancementRygels HD Texture pack AND HD Crysis Texture Pack 2016Maximum ImmersionCrysis 2 Nanosuit Voice (Crysis 2 did a lot of things wrong but the suit was awesome)Enjoy the game!nominate for farm or test of time award

												Crysis was a very good game and the first in a great series developed by Crytek and published by Electronic Arts in 2007. Crysis is a science-fiction first person shooter. You, the player, play as Nomad, an exceptional and strong-willed character determined to fight to survive. The game is primarily set on a North-Korean controlled island where they are attempting to uncover the mystery of a potential grand discovery. Nomad and his nano-suited military team mates and the United States army intervene, however the reveal of a greater power, named the Ceph, strongly influences and alters the story.This campaign is excellent. The campaign is a great example of a story that starts slow, but builds to a climax. The setting of being on one island suggests a limited campaign, however, the great areas of on the island and in the island create a nice variety of missions. I adore the fluidity and transition between missions within the campaign. For instance, you complete a mission and run to the extraction point - instead of the game taking you to a loading screen, it immediately starts the next mission, which is a massive positive. The only issue I encountered with the campaign is the mild relevance of the side missions. Nomad would have to gain intel from a North Korean camp, and while it adds some further dialogue in the story, it is not substantial. Also, it is really a standalone player game as your squad-members do not assist you in missions and are very useless.Gameplay is your standard first person shooter gameplay, The gameplay is fluid and solid. There is nothing more to elaborate on regarding shooting and cover. Driving is a nice feature but clunky as the vehicle is very sensitive to player controls. The issues I encountered within the gameplay section is the lack of ammo for an American gun and the very small variety of overall guns in the game. I had to rely on a North Korean assault rifle because there was no ammo to be found for my American Scar. There are some minor bugs such as the red dot on a red dot sight not appearing and the insane amount of bullets required to kill an armoured North Korean enemy. To kill an enemy would regularly take 75% of a magazine. To kill an Alien would take a larger amount of ammo, which is understandable as they are strong aliens, but for humans, that is very odd. The main disturbance regarding gameplay is the sheer stupidty of AI. Some enemies would run in circles while ally team mates would be useless in completing objectives, as stated prior.The graphics are incredible for a game developed in 2007. Crytek is known as a high-quality graphical company and they really emphasised that in Crysis. While the recommended settings were a Nvidia GT 8800, I could not play at ultra settings, even with my graphics card, which is odd as I had to play on very high settings with V Sync and Anti Aliasing turned off.Overall, this game is a good game. I only played the campaign and I can safely say I thoroughly enjoyed the experience. I played this game in around eight hours. It's a solid length of a game. I recommend the game at the Steam price of $19.99. Furthermore, I would strongly suggest buying the Maximum Edition that includes Crysis, Crysis: Warhead, and Crysis II. Three aspects in review:Campaign: 9/10Gameplay: 7.25/10Graphics: 8/10Overall: 8.25/10Thanks for reading my review!  Originally posted on January 21, 2010 Crysis is an absolutely incredible experience that defines why PC gaming is great. It's an open world shooter with graphics that are 2.5 years old and are still by far the most impressive offering on the market. It's gameplay is a varied hybrid of stealth and action in the proud tradition of Far Cry one, and although there are a few problems with the game, it is one you should not miss if you own a PC.Gameplay-As in it's spiritual successor, Far Cry, Crysis is a game that centers around island/tropics based combat in an open world with lots of vehicles and baddies with great AI that can use vehicles, flank, retreat, give orders, and call in unscripted backup. You hit multiple objectives using stealth or assault tactics and a wide variety of weapons.This much has not changed very much from Far Cry, and I see no problem with that. The AI very much Far Cry 1.5 AI, which is impressive considering Far Cry AI still tops many games on the market. Enemy vehicles still chase you relentlessly once you are discovered, and harder levels can be particularly brutal. You are not usually accompanied by many friendlies in a helpful manner, but there are certain fixed engagements where you encounter friendly AI, and they get the job done decently. It remains a lone-wolf experience for the majority of the game.The most major change comes in the form of the nano-suit, which allows speed, jumping/punching, and armor to rise to greater levels at the expense of energy, and the suit includes a cloaking device. This simple mechanic allows for a huge amount of fun to be had, especially in jungle infantry combat and in enemy camps.Another change would be the addition of on the fly weapon customization, a brilliant addition, and the ability to pick up attachments as you progress through the game. I will say that as gamers we do not always stop to examine the model of each weapon lying on the ground or even in an armory and as a result miss out on early instances of great attachments, such as the sniper scope. Could the auto-ammo-pick-up system from warhead be included in the next installment with a feature that picks up attachments you don't have as well? That would be wonderful. Also, the ability to suppress certain weapons would be welcome and not altogether unbalanced or "unrealistic". I could envision the shotgun and sniper rifle being suppressed but with a louder sound signature and working in game just fine.I will say the alien gameplay is a little less fun, as it was with mutants in far cry, and though the story remains interesting, the enemies are somewhat less interesting to fight (warhead partially helps with this) due to less intelligent tactics and repetitive attacks. Also, the introduction of Aliens generally is accompanied by more linear missions, which is not where this type of game shines. Far Cry had the same problem.Story- However, far cry also had a terrible story, with about as much cheese as anyone can handle. Crysis' story actually is quite decent, and they really take advantage of some cool cinematic techniques to tell it. The plot certainly makes more sense than Avatar's, and the pacing is better too. And what Avatar's technical visuals are for movies, Crysis' are for games.Visuals- Crysis is currently(Jan. 2010) the best looking game on the market for any gaming platform, and will most likely continue to stay there until Crysis 2. This has been the situation since Crysis was released in 2007! This gap is of course due largely to the economic impact of console markets and in turn the technical limitations of consoles, and Crysis really demonstrates this gap. The last great PC exclusive graphics engine, in all honesty. Not to mention that after patching and drivers it is quite well optimized, and though I must admit I have a 4870, it runs well on much worse hardware. The Character models and lighting effects are standouts in the visuals category, accompanied by the water and foliage effects. The alien ship also looks astounding.Also, the music is cinematic and the battle theme is really quite exceptional.All in all, Crysis is a graphics juggernaut that nothing on the market can really touch, and incredible shooter and gaming experience, and not a half bad-cinematic experience either (certainly better than any big-budget Michael Bay style film I've ever seen). This comes together in one amazing package that meets all expectations as far as I'm concerned, even if it could have improved in a few areas.

 Disclaimer This review is aimed at the single player portion of the game. Detail I first played this game back in 2007. It was the talk of the town, all because of it's advanced CryEngine I was so impressed that my Pentium Dual Core processor, 4GB RAM and my trusty Radeon 2600XT could run this on medium. I simply watched in awe of the images which were rendered before me. Since then I always used this as one of my go to benchmark games and tools - upgraded to an Intel Core 2 Quad Q8200 and NVIDIA 9800 GT and later to my previous rig: i7 870, 8GB RAM, and Radeon 5870. I could finally play this game smoothly on ultra at 1920 x 1080. It looked stunning.But, apart from the graphics department, how good is this game really?The plot is a mixed bag. It's no different from your typical action movie, but not bad either. I really didn't care about any of the characters, except for Psycho and prophet. Nomad (controlled by the player) has a stale personality, almost robot-like and emotionless, focussing only on the mission at hand. Crytek tried a few times to give the idea of emotion, but ultimately it still felt shallow.The game mechanics are very fluent. Movement and gunplay feels natural and faced paced – exactly what you want in a shooter. The Nano suit was a great new innovative idea, breathing new life into the generic state shooters usually are.The campaign maps are huge. The environments are unique, varying from lush jungles to dirt filled excavation sites.One major issue for me was optimization. Bear in mind that there came a point in time where Crysis reached it's limitation at fully utilization modern hardware. It was unable to fully utilise both my CPU and GPU – the CPU cores sometimes only being used between 20% and 40%. The GPU had similar results. There were a few scenes which the frames dropped below 60fps toward 20 to 30 fps, although it kept to 60 fps 95% of the time. This is an older game which was released when Core 2 Duo CPU’s were the gaming standard and the 9800 GTX was the cream of the crop. To expect that it should fully utilise modern hardware is ridiculous, but something to take note of. Verdict  The good  Beautiful graphics and environments. Huge open ended maps. Good game mechanics. The bad  Boring, unimaginative and forgettable characters. Unoptimized for modern hardware. Occasional frame drops.Overall, it’s a great game which I highly recommend. All PC gamers should pick this one up.

												If you , like me, were here to see if your latest PC could run Crysis maxed out and still hold a decent frame rate... I have bad news for you. It can't. But, do not dispair... After all these years I can look back, wisened in my old age, and realise that Crysis was never going to run well. The developers were using so many new, unrefined graphics techniques that the game by its very nature is not capable of running at a steady 60FPS, with all the graphics turned up to very high. And it never will be capable of holding a steady 60FPS. Guys, Crysis just runs badly. I'm afraid that's the hard truth we all have to swallow....Quick tip; if you find the frames chugging, just turn off, or turn down, the very bizarre motion blur effect. It murders the FPS, and really doesn't look especially good. Strange, no matter how fast I whip my head around I just can't seem to make the world blur like that....  But now that we've got that out of the way, does the game still hold up after all these years? Does it still look good, and is it still a good game? Good news; yes.Upon first starting Crysis my jaw landed somewhere between my nipples. It really is incredibly difficult to believe this game is nearly ten years old. And, it's equally mind blowing to realise just how much the Xbox360 and PS3 held back graphics advancements, considering where they were prior to console restrictions. In some areas of Crysis the foliage and lighting effects are still mind blowingly good, even by modern standards. Sure, the rock textures are vomit inducing, and the tree trunks look like the rear end of a horse, but the overall foliage detail is still extremely impressive. I just never get tired of shooting through foliage and seeing the physics effects.Gameplay wise I can only say this; "Oh, yeah. So this is what games were like before the CoD generation."You can lean! And go prone! You can change the fire mode of your gun! You can throw chickens at enemies! (Here's a challenge for you; see how far you can get in the game by murdering people only with thrown wildlife.)The enemies in Crysis really don't ♥♥♥♥♥ foot around, especially on harder difficulty settings. And frankly, I love it. Once they've spotted you they will murder your♥♥♥♥♥ Its genuinely challenging, and the nano suit is actually REQUIRED, or you will get your brains handed to you in five seconds flat. I haven't played a game that offers such wide open spaces, with such a feeling of freedom and realism, in a very long time. Crysis 3 is equally as challenging, as I recall, but just doesn't deliver the same feeling of space that Crysis 1 does. Crysis 1 feels like a real island, and although some may say the space is wasted, I say it does exactly what it's meant to; make you feel like you're in a real world situation.  In conclusion; Crysis is still pretty impressive as far as graphics go, but the real surprise for me was to realise just how good a game it still is. I strongly suggest giving it a go again, especially if you're an 80's baby like myself. Take a dip back into the good old days of first person shooters, folks, you'll be pleasantly surprised.

												I only got round to playing Crysis in 2015, although I've been meaning to for years!From what I'd seen, I was under the impression that you'd play a kind of semi-indestructable super soldier in this game, dashing and jumping around at high speed and slicing through dozens of enemy soldiers with ease, but really it plays more like you're just a fairly standard FPS soldier dude with a few perks. I found myself not bothering with things like the stealth and speed mode very often as they both drain your energy incredibly quickly. On hard difficulty, a few well-placed enemy bullets can still take you down if you're not careful so you don't really feel invulnerable.The gameplay is fairly standard FPS fare, akin to Call Of Duty or whatever, with open-ish world elements but lots of set pieces. The game world never feels as open as, say, the Far Cry series and you are pretty much railroaded into tackling things in order, though how you approach each set piece is up to you and you do feel that you can take a variety of approaches to solve the obstacles you encounter.The graphics have really stood the test of time, It didn't feel particularly dated.My only gripe was that the campaign only took me 10 hours to play through - and I didn't exactly rush through it. If I'm honest, the storyline is also very standard and unengaging, following a rather cliched 'US saves the world from alien invasion that is unwittingly aided by the nasty Asians' formula that's all too familiar by now.Overall, I'd say that if you're a fan of the FPS genre, you've never played Crysis before and you see if on sale for a few pounds/dollars (like I did) then it's definitely worth picking up! It's an enjoyable, if short, experience.

												1st 2/3 of the game was fun. Open world, you chose how to fight. Lush, living world that is inviting you to explore it. I really did like this part of the game as it was very engaging. Graphics still look pretty awesome despite the fact the game was released so long ago. Combat system felt very fluid as you can use anything as a weapon basically -  You can use enemy soldiers as bowling balls, drown them, toss them off a cliff, club them, get into a fist fight, hit them with trucks or boats and more.The world itself is very interactive as you can pick up and throw chickens, local wildlife, rock, branches, pots, fruits, barrels and much more to slam the enemy with. Entire trees will topple over in heavy gun / grenade fire. Soft targets such as huts can be completly destroyed by gunfire / grenades, ramming, or tossing enemy soldiers though the walls.Desite all the good this game has to offer, I do have a couple gripes though that really detracted from my overall experience.1 - Enemies shrug of rediculous amount of damage. I can shoot a guy in the knee - He still manages to sprint as if nothing happened. I can shoot a guy in the head...oh wait he's wearing a basebal cap that allows him to tank 3-4 hits from an assault rifle. What? Enemies really should be more responsive to damage, especially when shot in unprotected areas....like the face...or the balls. Not moving at either 100% or dead.2 - Enemies movement can be unrealisicaly rediculous. Dancing side to side  in the open to dodge bullets, tanking and strafing. I'm not a fan of this in any shooter. With a game that looks as realistic as crysis, I expected different.3 - The last 1/3 of the game - Punishment. What happened? This here was the real turnoff for me - The game turned into a generic, boring rail shooter with extremely, useless, needy, comrade AI that curses you out left and right for not moving fast enough. Your character turns into a yes man that just runs around, taking orders from everyone to do every single thing. Story also falls apart and generally by this point in the campain I really found it increasingly difficult to care...I just wanted it to end as it just got so boring. The alien AI requires no tactics to fight as their combat manuvers are pretty much limited to strafing you from range, or charge in and slash you. With the earlier part of the game playing so well, I'm not sure why they would go this route - by the end the game is nothing like how it started, it feels very cramped and controlled. TLDR - The 1st 2/3's of the game is fun and well done. The Last acts, not worth my time - The game devolved into a heavily scripted, cramped railshooter. At the end....I'm kind of neutral on this one. Now if only we had a button that wasn't thumbs up or thumbs down....

												"Can your computer run Crysis?"Despite the fact that it has been many years since Crysis came out, you still hear this every once in a while (usually in jest). I definitely wasn't worried about my GTX 670 and i5-3750k having trouble.I had psyched myself up about the visuals so much that my initial impression was "well this doesn't look half bad..." and then I remembered how old the game is. And I nearly peed myself. Even the cutscenes were rendered in the game engine, so the game always had a consistent visual style.The appeal for anybody who plays Crysis is of course the beautiful graphics, so I wasn't expecting much from the story or gameplay. As it turns out the gameplay was really good; the controls were nice and tight, even when you drive vehicles. Even flying a VTOL (those flying things that work like helicopters) and floating around in zero-gravity was intuitive, which is saying a lot.Although Crysis is obviously a linear game, the map was usually open enough that as long as you are going in the general direction of your next objective (which is what your character, Nomad, would be doing anyway) you won't feel constrained at all.The one area where gameplay suffered was the enemy AI. I found them laughably stupid, and took great sadistic pleasure in luring large numbers of them into small choke points where I could easily mow them down.On the opposite end of the spectrum, there were a couple of areas where I really wasn't given sufficient tools to complete the objectives. One example was a map where I was trying to destroy a few anti-aircraft emplacements. I ended up having two enemy helicopters following me around, and I only found one rocket launcher on the entire map. It was a pretty open map so I may have missed the others, but they weren't in any of the obvious places. So I ended up just running around cloaked as much as possible until I managed to complete my objective. Oh, and once that was complete the helicopters magically went away.The nano suit is the biggest aspect of the game (besides the graphics) that differentiates Crysis from other military shooters. The suit allows you to choose between several modes: strength, speed, armor, and cloak. Thanks to the nano suit you can play the game using a variety of play styles. One of my favorite things to do was to sneak into a complex cloaked dual-wielding a couple of silenced pistols with laser sights. It then became a nice little exercise in shooting everyone in the head one at a time before they figured out that I was there (and given that the AI was so stupid they would only figure out that I was there if they got a nice long look at me while uncloaked.) Ninja Nomad.The story can be summed up pretty quickly: North Koreans and aliens on a tropical island.Once you know that, nothing will surprise you. There were no plot twists, no sudden betrayals or finding out someone was a double agent or anything. But I was fine with that, because that wasn't why I was there anyway. That being said, I did like the ending; it was a satisfying "hell yeah!" at the end of a nice ten-hour campaign.If you are at all interested in playing Crysis, now is the best time to do it. The game is old enough that it is really cheap but it is still new enough to look good.

												Crysis. Oh dear Crysis. It's the fabled representative of the "PC master race" cause. Is it a good game? Well, lets see. The story is a bit cliched, reeking of "Humanity screwed around with something they shouldn't have" trope, but it is handled with a bit of creativity. You are Nomad, a member of Raptor team, an elite group of soldiers for the U.S Military. It's 2020, and you and you're team are dispatched to rescue some hostages from the Korean People's Army. The hostages were apparantly scientists and archaeologists who had found something buried in the biggest mountain in the area. So, you initally get seperated from your team, and one of your squadmates who barely has any character gets killed off screen by something who "Tore his body up bad". From there, you trek you're way across the island you're set on, killing wave after wave of KPA troops. You learn a fanatical general, General Kyong, is in charge of the Korean Military occupation of the island, and you find one of the hostages. Then you start to get a sense that something else is on this island with you. Something inhuman. Raptor team's leader, Prophet, gets kidnapped by the same thing that killed your other squadmate in the opening, and you eventually get to General Kyong in a rather anticlimatic boss fight, ending with learning that yes. Aliens are in fact real, and that they really love the cold. From there, it just devolves to "Stop the Aliens from taking over the world." I say the story is cliched, sure, but it has it's moments. The voice acting is top notch, with at least some of the actors caring for their roles. Sure, almost all of Raptor team seems to be full of racial and cultural stereotypes, but they grow on you after a while. Heck, Psycho, the british personality, got so popular he even got his own spin-off game, but i'll get to that another time. As for your character, Nomad, he's a little bland. He hardly says anything, as per the first person shooter method, but dare I say, even Master Chief from the Halo series has more character than him. He just seems like the standard, military type who's honorable, and tough. And thats about it. All in all, it's an okay sci-fi plot. Nothing too new brought to the table, but not terrible.The gameplay is pretty damn solid. The biggest table-turner and innovation you have in the game, is the Nanosuit. Imagine if  Master Chief's suit got a major upgrade. Like, major. Actually, imagine this. Imagine if Master Chief's suit, got the abilities of Flash, The Predator, and Hulk. Thats the Nanosuit in a nutshell. It has four distinct modes to choose from. Strength, Speed, Cloak, and Armor. You can only use one at a time, but changing them up on the fly will help you win many, many battles. The Cloak is a little abusive, but thats what Delta level difficulty is for, where the enemy will often see your little invisibility trick. Armor mode is also another one thats pretty abusive, but it does make combat so much easier. Speaking of combat, the firefights in this game are pretty intense sometimes. You do have a somewhat limited arsenal. Theres no carrying around ten different kinds of guns like Duke Nukem 3D or Half Life, but it's no two weapon limit either. You get two primary weapons, two pistols, ten grenades, a heavy weapon like an RPG, C4 charges, and your bare hands. The primary weapon variety in this game is diverse, with 3 kinds of machine guns, and a few others I won't spoil here. Almost every weapon has customization options, like different kinds of scopes, or laser sights. Now, about your enemies. Don't think for a second, that just because the KPA are made entirely of a rather low tech militia, that they aren't dangerous. Each and every one of them can and will kill you without a thought. The A.I that drives them is also nice to watch. While they sometimes do goofy things, like stare at walls, and shout that they are throwing a grenade, but the grenade never comes, they sometimes do rather intelligent things, like flank you, take cover in the bushes, and converge on you from all different angles. The manner in which you take on the numerous amount of KPA infantry is also pretty expansive. Do you go in, all guns blazing, tearing and blowing everything up in sight? Or do you prefer to be the human equivalent of the Predator, sneaking in and taking them out one by one? The choice is yours. Theres also a fair amount of vehicular combat as well, but these vary in the fun factor. For example, the section where you blast your way through a valley in a tank is beyond the term awesome, but other sections like the VTOL retreat, just feel a bit broken, especially in control. Oh, and then theres the latter half of the game. With the aliens. Once you leave the mountain halfway through the game, say bye bye to diverse tactics and combat options, and say hello to generic "Just use a really BFG to kill them!". Seriously, the alien combat is the dullest and most boring thing I experienced with this game. There is no specific weakness to exploit with the aliens, just fill them full of projectiles until they crash and burn. To poorly balance this, the final boss of the game, has easily exploitable weaknesses, that make the fight over in less than ten minutes. Overall, I say that Crysis's gameplay is fun as all gets out, until the second you beat General Kyong, and then it all goes downhill from there. Thats just my opinion however. The multiplayer, on the other hand, well...I heard it was fun when people actually played it. The Power Struggle gametype seems like a creative idea, outright destroying the enemy team's base? Sounds pretty awesome to me.In terms of graphics, yes, Crysis is pretty to look at. The world is very detailed, and realistic. However, I promise you, that you'll be spending about twenty minutes in the settings of the game, tweaking and testing, until you get it to look exactly how you want it to look. Once you do though, you'll wonder how this was a game made in 2007, with it's vibrant colors, detailed textures, realistic physics, and excellent sound design. Also, the soundtrack by Inon Zur is amazing, with flourishes coinciding with whats going on around you.Overall, for it's okay story, pretty fun gameplay, and it's nice-to-look-at graphics, I give Crysis a 6/10. It's a must have for any fan of the first-person-shooter genre, and I highly reccommend it.

												Don't expect a plot beyond your generic Sci-fi stuff. The gameplay, however, is still incredibly fun, and offers so many options that every encounter can be different. Your Nanosuit has four abilities, and the use of each one drains your suit's Energy bar. Fortunately it, as well as your health, regenerate in a decent pace to allow quick, exciting and varied combat sessions. Combined with cars and boats, as well as fairly open level designs, each fight in Crysis can be a fresh experience unlike many other shooters.Your armor has "Speed" to dart around the battlefield and rush up to enemies to knock them down. "Strength" for stronger melee, as well as high jumps (one of the favorite fights in my playthrough was using this to jump over a fence into an enemy base, and then run around their rooftops, hopping from one to the other and gunning them down as I go). "Armor" to absorb damage and hasten the recovery of Energy and Health. And lastly, "Invisibility". The stealth aspect of the game isn't as refined as it could be - silent takedowns aren't too silent and you can't hide bodies - but still enjoyable.Weapons are also modifiable to a small degree with different attachments, adding yet another layer of tactics and allowing different approaches.  Sadly, even on the toughest difficulty (which isn't as maddeningly frustrating as Modern Warfare was for me), I didn't feel a need to switch weapons out of necessity. Just for variation's sake. You can safely beat the game just with the standard rifle you'll find. But, again, experimenting is fun here.It took me 12 hours to complete, but I expect to have another playthrough eventually. Both because it's honestly a very fun shooter, and because by the end of the game you really get the hang of using your suit, vehicles and weapons, that you'll feel like revisiting those early levels where you were still fumbling around. Seeing as this isn't a linear game, those early levels /are/ worth revisiting, because the experience will thankfully be different.P.S.It's still a very pretty game, too!

												Crysis is something else: stunning graphics, an underused setting, an epic story, and an enjoyable multiplayer game to boot. People playing this will likely recall FarCry, with good reason. Crysis is the evolution of that title, using a new engine, but keeping the general feel of a 'hell in paradise'. It all begins with what looks to be like a simple rescue mission. You and your group, equipped with the latest in nano-augmented suit technology, parachute into North-Korean-occupied territory to find an archaeologist. It should be a simple rescue mission, but something is definitely wrong, and as you continue through the island you've been dropped into, you'll find that there are more players in this game than you think. The action in the single-player experience is as intensive as you want to make it. Your nano-suit grants you a variety of abilities, each of which augment what you can do and, depending on your use, how you play. You can increase your strength, adding damage to your attacks and allowing you to jump a dozen feet in the air; you can increase your speed, allowing you to run blindingly around your opponents; you can increase your armor, allowing your suit energy to take damage until it runs out and you start to bleed; or you can enter cloak mode, arguably one of the most useful suit abilities, which makes you invisible for a short time, allowing you to sneak around your opponents and confront them on your own terms.Running into the fray, guns blazing, is always an option but a difficult one. It doesn't take a lot to bring you down, and when you have at least half a dozen enemies gunning for you, things can get real deadly real quick. Hiding in the underbrush allows you to stay out of sight of enemies, which is crucial when lookout towers are scattered across the territory that you need to move through. The result is gameplay that tends to be tense at times, but at others sometimes just feels like the bushes are playing a game of hot-potato, and you're the potato.The game offers some magnificent environments, a notable difference from the usual faire in its genre. Maps span kilometres, which is an impressive feat that allows the game to be played differently than just running through small corridors. Though visually stellar, the problem with the environments is that many of them consist only of a valley that makes you move in a straight line to get to your target, as opposed to the wide-open nature of others. These valleys are probably more open than most FPS games, but they're a stark contrast to other sections of the game, and feel all the more constrained because of it.The presentation is pretty top-notch: great acting, great story, and a pace that keeps the action going throughout.The single player campaign may be fun, but it does end, and when it does, the multiplayer game is where you go to continue the action. Luckily, it delivers quite excellently. Crysis has definitely raised the stakes when it comes to graphics, and is probably going to be used as a technical benchmark for many years to come. Its stunning environments and interesting gameplay that changes with the suit's powers create a very enjoyable experience.

												I have to go out on a limb here and say that this is actually one of the best FPS games I ever played, period.Others may point out the deficiencies, but through the curious way I experienced this game it has ultimately assumed the status of an absolute classic in my eyes.That experience I mention is this: On my first ever playthrough, my rig was such that the game crashed as soon as I entered the final act - all that water and all those explosions, you dig? - and so I never actually knew that it was the final act. In my mind the game stretched on into inifinity - and what an infinity it was. The game goes through three distinct phases, each more jaw-droppingly perfect than the last. At first, one is navigating a jungly-coated tropical island world, evading - or annihilating, though this was never as fun for me - conventional, dastardly Korean forces in a manner strongly remeniscent of the original Far Cry (for me at least, Far Cry didn't really have any stealth component, though i did everything i could to force it to play like a stealth shooter nonetheless) In the second phase, all-out conflict has broken out and, while you can continue to play as a phantom if you wish, the stakes and scale soar upwards into 'epic' territory. In the third phase, you discover a vast and fantastic secret lurking within the island, exploring this secret in a state of permawonder, before re-emerging into a drastically altered form of the second phase, to see out the game.My initial experience was cut short most of the way through the third phase, so in my mind it was, as I've said, neverending, and by jebus that neverending game was FPS fantasy made reality. It really is just an awesome game.Quite apart form the graphics, which are to this day superior to almost any other offering of comprable setting (visually if not technolgically, though the tech is still close), the gameplay is tight and perfectly polished. This is the kind of game that, while vaguely linear, allows a player to turn 100m of linear progression into around 1km of side-track meandering and sneaking more or less throughout the entire experience. One can craft one's own adventure here, as surely as any of those gimmicky kids books from the '90s, and just as everyone had envisioned in their wildest dreams back then this adventure is lush, endless and full of wonders more wonderous than the last.The gameplay is consistent and with the possible exception of the final moments of the second phase, in which combat is more or less forced on you and the game literally ejects any background action in an effort - only marginally succesful - to turn your final stage into some kind of arena, it is consistently entertaining.Why should you buy this game? Because your computer may very well finally be able to run it in something approaching max settings, because it is one of the best FPS experiences you will ever play, and because it is streets, miles ahead of any other similar game released in the years before or the years after.

												Let me start by saying Crysis is a very different game to what I expected.  Boy was I wrong and I am GLAD for it. I was expecting to step into the shoes of a Master Chief style tank/super soldier that could Clint Eastwood his way through the fight. Crysis instead puts you into the shoes of an American Special Forces soldier and asks you to think like one. It was VERY refreshing and VERY welcome. The Nano Suit (think super soldier suit) which you wear doesn't make you an invincible force of nature but instead makes you feel like you are wearing a USEFUL military designed peice of hardware. It expands the natural abilities that a special forces soldier would need and use, not grant him super powers. The suit merely gives you options to tackle any situation how you see fit and THAT is what makes this game clever. I also want to put on record that I know and understand that the Crysis series is designed to break computers. I played this game on Maximum settings as intended and it is FREAKING GORGEOUS. A game that came out in 2007 still beats out most modern day titles that I have seen in 2014. It is wonderful to be awed by the graphics of a game to this extent and I am blessed to own a computer that could handle it easily (although I do feel that this would be a sticking point for many players with underpowered hardware). Just because my experience was great, doesn't mean your experience will be. Please understand that your milage could vary from my review!So I finished the game in 12 hours (which is leaning on the shorter side)  but the story and the pacing complimented this length nicely so it is hard to chalk this as adrawback. I also played with a gamepad (Xbox 360) but it is easy to tell that Crysis is designed with the Keyboard and Mouse in mind. It works don't get me wrong!
