												What is there to say about Crysis that has not already been said. It is a georgeous masterpiece that looks amazing and stands the test of time. When this game came out in 2007 I can assure you that almost nobody had a powerful enough machine to run this game maxed out. As much as I could say about the graphics it is more than just a tech demo and is an amazing game in just about every other aspect. The game takes place in the year 2020 were you play as a nano-suited supersoldier named Nomad. This suit has many features such as cloak mode, armour mode, strength made, and speed mode. It can also help the user survive in extreme cold and heat. You are sent to the Korean controlled Lingshan Islands when you recieve a distress signal from a scientist named Rosenthal. As you continue your mission members of your team start to die in weird ways and things get stranger and stranger. Little does the team know that their suits have awakened an alien race hidden in the island. I won't spoil the ending because this is a game that you should play for yourself. The gameplay of Crysis is quite fun. This FPS puts you on the island and it is huge and allows you to choose your own path to the next objective. Do you sneak in through the woods and make it undetected or storm in in an armored car. The choice is yours. As for the weapons there are several modern and futeristic weapons ranging from sub-machine guns, assault rifles, sniper rifles, pistols, shotguns, rocket launchers, modified alien mini turrets, and even your own fists. As for multiplayer there are two main modes. There is a standard deathmatch mode and then there is the power struggle mode. In power struggle there are two teams, each with their own main base. The point of the game is to capture smaller command points and to kill members of the other team until you have enough money to get a really powerful weapon to take out the enemy's main base and win the game. going back to graphics there are some more things to talk about. The game came out right around when windows vista came out and supposedly can take advantage of its features. Mainly it can run in DX10 mode although it was mainly built around DX9. You normally can't acces very high settings on DX9 so windows xp users would be out of luck but there are two ways around this. The first is to go into the configuraton file and edit it to force very high settings on DX9 wich looks almost exactly the same as on DX10 with the only difference being some subtle lighting effects only on DX10. The other way is to get a version of DX10 that will run on windows xp that was released a year or two ago, go to the files for Crysis and change the name of the file called D3D9 to D3D10 and then change D3D10 to D3D9, and then to go into the lauch options on Steam and type in this line " -DX10". This will allow you to run Crysis on the highest settings in DX10 mode on windows xp. This game is more than worth the 20 dollars it costs to get. I hope this review was helpful and that you enjoy this masterpiece as much as I have.

												There's a great sense of empowerment by running through a jungle stealthed up to an enemy base, turning off your cloak and turning on your armour and systematically taking out every enemy in that base as your rifle carefully guides you to your target. The fact that that's just one way of many to go about your objectives is one of the reasons it's a great game.Crysis' strengths are numerous. Gun-play feels satisfying, both the actual shooting of enemies as well as the feedback of toying around with attachments, to the extent that if you played the game as a straight shooter, you probably wouldn't be disappointed. That the movement options available to you wide and varied, from the slow and stealthy approach to the super fast leaping-and-bounding traversal. That you can approach an encounter in a myriad of ways, some because it will be more effective and some because it'll just be plain fun. That these are all wrapped up in a gorgeous visual presentation and audio that gives weight to your movement and minute-to-minute actions is just an icing on an already yummy cake.Really though it's the freedom of the game to let you do things the way you want to that is its strongest aspect, clearly in exchange for a hum-drum plot that, whilst a little awkward, changes tone and direction in the second half to something that is at least a little more engaging. That each objective is punctuated by an open enviroment with traversal allowing you to explore the islands you operate on with no real time limit gives the game a much bigger scope than simply moving from one fire-fight to the next, preventing any sense of boredom creeping in, but ultimately it's down to you to keep things as entertaining as you want them to be. So yes, again, you could just shoot your way through everything, but perhaps you'll strap some explosives to a truck, drive up to a base stealthed, dive out of the car at the last moment and watching the vehicle explode and the base erupt into chaos as you sleuth around it to eliminate any opposition. Or maybe you'll just zoom around at maximum speed punching your targets and sending them flying into walls. It's your choice.Whilst the freedom in play is reduced in the second half of the game with the plot's directional change, the feeling of the hunter is swapped around and instead of using your suit's powers for offensive actions, you're using them to survive in any manner you seem most suitable. With a pace that's consistent and overall length that is neither too short nor overstays its welcome as well as proving as much replayability as you have creativity, Crysis is a great first person shooter with a high quota for enjoyment.

												Just to get it out of the way: yes, this game is gorgeous, one of the best looking of all time and it still is today. However, I've never been particularly a good graphics kind of gamer, I'm more about the gameplay in games. Luckily, the gameplay in Crysis is a lot of fun. The thing that really makes it is the nanosuit, giving you four different abilities to use: speed, strength, armour, and invisibility. Stealth is also a crucial strategy, especially when there are dozens of enemies you have to eliminate. The enemy AI is very good as well, it works very well with stealth and during combat they will try to flank you. Add in the different weapon customizations, there are a lot of combinations to use in enemy encounters that it will keep you entertained for the duration of the campaign. The level design is also nice and open, giving you even more options like sniping and using vehicles.The story in the game isn't particularly good, but this isn't the kind of game you play for the story, you should play it for the gameplay and graphics. However, where the game really faulters, is in the last two or two-and-a-half hours of the campaign when you start battling the aliens. The aliens just aren't as fun to fight as the Koreans and don't allow for much variation in the ways you want to fight them.Crysis is a great game, particularly is you like experimentation in the ways you want to handle the enemy encounters.  Half the fun is just seeing what kind of stuff you can get away with, and I love that.

												More than half a decade has passed, but Crysis still impresses with its gameplay and graphics, though the it stumbles in its second half. In Crysis, you play as a soldier equipped with a nanosuit that lets you switch between 4 powers (Armour, Speed, Strength and Cloak) which, when combined with technically linear yet impressively large and open levels, provides many ways to approach situations. Throw in vehicles (which aren't that nice to control but are still fun to drive and blow up), destructible environments and ragdolling and you have a wonderful FPS experience... for the first half of the game. The second half of the game replaces the North Koreans with aliens as the main enemy and abruptly replaces its large levels with standard linear fare. It's pretty decent at first, but uninteresting alien combat and generic missions soon dull the experience. If that wasn't enough, an annoying escort mission, a potentially engaging VTOL sequence marred by crappy controls and an underwhelming final level pop up to turn an average second half into a tiring and fustrating experience that sits at odds with the not quite perfect but still sublime first half. Despite all these issues, the first half alone make Crysis worth the purchase, if not as a standalone product then at least in the Maximum Edition bundle, which includes Crysis Warhead.

												In 2007 Turkish-German game developer Crytek released ‘Crysis’, a cryengine-built first person shooter which exceeded the graphical norm at the time more than any other game ever did or would later do. Almost no computer could run it at the time and for many years it would be the ideal game to test new gaming PC’s with, but even disregarding this main strength of the game Crysis is a very decent FPS. In Crysis you take the role of an American soldier named ‘Nomad’ who is part of an elite squadron of nanosuit-equipped soldiers . You are sent to the Lingshan islands in the pacific to rescue a team of archeologists from North-Korean soldiers who took the place over. Story is not quite the part of the game that deserves closest examination because of that it is quite generic. After all, even back in 2007 there were already quite a few games that had the player kill soldiers while playing as an American soldier himself, but luckily the story takes a bit of a back seat here. It would not be until Crysis 2 that other things than combat would be given some attention. In terms of story delivery there is also nothing new here.What you would want to play Crysis for, if not the superb graphics, would be its gameplay and it does this quite well. Although it uses pretty standard FPS mechanisms the nanosuit makes for a welcome addition. Basically the suit gives you a choice of four superpowers, which consume from one general energy bar. There is a speed mode, pretty self-explanatory, a cloak mode that makes you largely invisible, a power mode that lets you jump higher and fling heavy objects and an armour mode. Using whatever improvements your power gives you costs energy and generally this system holds up pretty well. It is nice that you are given the choice between stealthing a section with the cloak or fighting through it normally, and if you choose the latter you can also pick different tactics with either the speed or the armour mode.  A nice small addition on the side is that you are at any time able to modify your weapon, which means you can pick your sight, add a suppressor or make other small modifications. The game also excels in giving the player freedom. Before Crytek set about on making Crysis they made the original Far Cry. Why these developers are so attached to the word ‘cry’ remains a mystery. But anyway, Far Cry was an open world game which was, like Crysis, set on a tropical island and sometimes it seems as if the developers carved a big and wide linear path out of Far Cry’s sandbox to make Crysis because Crysis feels about as unlinear as a linear game can be. The entire game has a structure similar to Half Life 2, in that you are never teleported to a different location but always go there yourself. There are almost no missions that all of a sudden take place somewhere else unless the last mission had you go there by yourself. Some objectives give you entire towns to play around in, a lot of the houses can be smashed up and most objects can be grabbed and thrown as weapons. What also makes this game feel like some fenced-off sandbox is the completely free use of vechiles. When you need to go to the next firefight you can walk there if you want, or you can get in a car which the game just puts outside most villages. Driving mechanics are not very good though, so if you are being shot at you are in more danger in a car than on foot.Although Crysis is indeed a very good FPS it does have a few minor issues I want to mention. Firstly that would be the story. I understand that a game like this leaves little room for something outrageously good, but they could perhaps have done a little less effort to make the North-Koreans look like jerks because in a game based around so much military excessive force, as showcased in a level where you take part in a big tank offensive, making the enemy seem evil just puts the entire game in a big cliché. Of course in a game with such a simple story you want to have your side as the goodies and the other side to be the baddies, but emphasizing that so much makes it all feel a bit fake. Some enemies come across as silly cartoon villains. My other nibbles mostly restrict to specific sections and mentioning them spoils parts of the game for you, so be warned about the following part. What peeved me a bit about one level that takes place in an alien space ship was that the entire place is extremely disorienting. Although that bit still looks extremely gorgeous graphics-wise, I found myself moving through the same looped corridor about five times before I found the right way by accident and the beauty loses something if it is forced upon you for so long. Another annoying part was one section where your squadmate, ‘Prophet’, has a damaged nanosuit which means you have to escort him and bring him to some kind of heat source every few seconds to prevent him from dying. It is not even hard at all and the combat is not harder with him around, so the entire thing just feels like a silly delay.  On the side, I found the game’s soundtrack to be very unimaginative. It does nothing to increase the atmosphere.So, in conclusion I would certainly recommend Crysis, even today. Although the graphics don’t excel anymore and the story is pretty rubbish, the gameplay is still very nice and you have plenty of liberty to explore the nanosuits potential, and that certainly outweighs the game’s few issues.

												There's a great sense of empowerment by running through a jungle stealthed up to an enemy base, turning off your cloak and turning on your armour and systematically taking out every enemy in that base as your rifle carefully guides you to your target. The fact that that's just one way of many to go about your objectives is one of the reasons it's a great game.Crysis' strengths are numerous. Gun-play feels satisfying, both the actual shooting of enemies as well as the feedback of toying around with attachments, to the extent that if you played the game as a straight shooter, you probably wouldn't be disappointed. That the movement options available to you wide and varied, from the slow and stealthy approach to the super fast leaping-and-bounding traversal. That you can approach an encounter in a myriad of ways, some because it will be more effective and some because it'll just be plain fun. That these are all wrapped up in a gorgeous visual presentation and audio that gives weight to your movement and minute-to-minute actions is just an icing on an already yummy cake.Really though it's the freedom of the game to let you do things the way you want to that is its strongest aspect, clearly in exchange for a hum-drum plot that, whilst a little awkward, changes tone and direction in the second half to something that is at least a little more engaging. That each objective is punctuated by an open enviroment with traversal allowing you to explore the islands you operate on with no real time limit gives the game a much bigger scope than simply moving from one fire-fight to the next, preventing any sense of boredom creeping in, but ultimately it's down to you to keep things as entertaining as you want them to be. So yes, again, you could just shoot your way through everything, but perhaps you'll strap some explosives to a truck, drive up to a base stealthed, dive out of the car at the last moment and watching the vehicle explode and the base erupt into chaos as you sleuth around it to eliminate any opposition. Or maybe you'll just zoom around at maximum speed punching your targets and sending them flying into walls. It's your choice.Whilst the freedom in play is reduced in the second half of the game with the plot's directional change, the feeling of the hunter is swapped around and instead of using your suit's powers for offensive actions, you're using them to survive in any manner you seem most suitable. With a pace that's consistent and overall length that is neither too short nor overstays its welcome as well as proving as much replayability as you have creativity, Crysis is a great first person shooter with a high quota for enjoyment.

Posted: May 17, 2014
												Ah the infamous Crysis. A game that required such high graphical settings to run it perfectly when it was released, there actually wasn't a computer available that could run it at those settings. Nowaways, it's not such a chore but the game still has heavy requirements. But it shows as this is a graphically beautiful game. But since gameplay comes before graphics, how does it play? Very well in fact. It is a first person shooter, which I usually avoid unless the game has an extra quality to make it stand out. Crysis places you, for most of the game, in indivudual mission areas which are huge. It's not quite an open world experience but it comes close, as you need to navigate to your objective and complete it, all the while dodging or kill hostiles. The other thing that sets the game apart is the Nanosuit; in this game it features four modes, which are strength, armor, speed, and stealth. Strength gives you a super jump and steady aim, armor reduces damage, speed makes you run faster, and stealth allows you cloak and ambush enemies or avoid them altogther. Of course the trick is that you can't have them all active at one time and you have a limited energy reserve which needs to recharge once empty. Trying to balance these out is half of the fun as you need to strategize and think on the fly if things go wrong.Crysis also features a good selection of weaponry, with explosives ranging from a missile launcher to claymore mines, along with single or dual wield pistols, and several different automatic and semi-automatic rifles. On these you can equip iron, or reflex sights, silencers, scopes, whatever you want (depending on the weapon). Some even offer non-lethal ammo or incendiary ammo. A couple of spots in the game get a little claustrophobic and hard to navigate, and the story isn't the game's strong point (secret U.S. rescue mission near Korea goes wrong, and aliens appear out of nowhere requiring fighting against both the aliens and Korean troops) but it's worth a pickup. Of note is the fact that online multiplayer for this game is being shut down in Summer of 2014 so when purchasing, keep in mind you'll have only the single player campaign.The game is highly recommended.

												Just to get it out of the way: yes, this game is gorgeous, one of the best looking of all time and it still is today. However, I've never been particularly a good graphics kind of gamer, I'm more about the gameplay in games. Luckily, the gameplay in Crysis is a lot of fun. The thing that really makes it is the nanosuit, giving you four different abilities to use: speed, strength, armour, and invisibility. Mixing and matching these four modes is a lot of fun, and allows for a lot of experimentation during combat. Stealth is also a crucial strategy, especially when there are dozens of enemies you have to eliminate. The enemy AI is very good as well, it works very well with stealth and during combat they will try to flank you. Add in the different weapon customizations, there are a lot of combinations to use in enemy encounters that it will keep you entertained for the duration of the campaign. The level design is also nice and open, giving you even more options like sniping and using vehicles.The story in the game isn't particularly good, but this isn't the kind of game you play for the story, you should play it for the gameplay and graphics. However, where the game really faulters, is in the last two or two-and-a-half hours of the campaign when you start battling the aliens. The aliens just aren't as fun to fight as the Koreans and don't allow for much variation in the ways you want to fight them.Crysis is a great game, particularly is you like experimentation in the ways you want to handle the enemy encounters.  Half the fun is just seeing what kind of stuff you can get away with, and I love that.

												Regardless of the date of production of this title, it gets a solid 10/10 for being polished.  That said, it was ahead of its time, and I beleive has had an impact on the industry and customer satisfaction even across genres due to the hardware driven nature of this title. Even if you do not delve into the hardware and system tweaking discussions that can be evoked by even mentioning the name Crysis at all, you are left with a great game conceptually and artistically.  The story-telling and voice/character acting are very seamless, and all the entire architecture of the game design is cohesive.  I was pleasently surprised to see the game evolve from remote island views to frozen SCI-FI worlds that are revealed in a manner that is very enthralling.  The plot and enemy design are the best things about this game to me, and they are why I think it is hard to put this game down even years after its debut (although the graphics are what made me interested in the game to begin with).    Unfortunately, it has taken all those years since its release for me to fully appreciate and realize this, as I could not get to the interesting parts without system lags interfering with the enjoyable quality of the game.  I found the game hard to enjoy at 15FPS, and I think anyone who has played this game on maximum settings without frame drops would not trade the experience. When Crysis came out, you would be lucky to get 30FPS on maxed out settings on a medium-high end PC.  This probably is no longer the case and you can enjoy what was at the time about the closest thing to being in control of an interactive movie on your system. This game continues to push hardware limits, and today is probably much more accessible to the average gamer than it was when it was first released and barely playable without spending a mere fortune.  The graphics are just as stunning as the physics, and the CRY-engine is polished but can be laggy at times compared to more light-weight games (depending on your system specifications).  The most optimized platforms at max settings continue to respect real-world dynamics and rigid body interactions/physics in a more satisfying manner than most competitive games/engines do with respect to fluid/solid body motions and raycasting/tracing in my opinion. I did find the environments and modeling of terrain to be more photorealistic in Crysis 1 as compared to its sequel; however, my system still has trouble handling the DX-11 patches for Crysis-2 on max settings on HD6990 Radeon and IntelX990.  This game is fun just because it is hard to talk about it without discussing the hardware and graphics, but I do think the animation style, branding and abundance of environmental details are what carried this game into public visibility and have secured it a place in videogame history.  At the end of the day, it is a beautiful game with extreme longevity with regards to its visual presentation.

												I've been itching to be the badass in the suit for some time, and as our protagonist is an uber-macho ultra-masculine Iron Man, it can be quite entertaining to tromp around in his NanoBoots. However I was disappointed by some of the glaring technical issues which have been left unattended by CryTek since its arrival on Steam.You wear the NanoSuit in the first iteration of the photorealistic experience, becoming the ultimate soldier. Prepare to Maximum your way through enemy forces, alien strongholds and countless gorgeously rendered trees and foliage.Crysis was for nearly a decade the gold standard for performance: "Sure the server's fast, but will it run Crysis?" Modern systems can still be tasked by the demanding CryEngine in its earliest release. Unfortunately it has not aged well, and graphical flaws can break the visual flow, such as spawning objects incorrectly and even breaking mission targets.Electronic Arts and Crytek issued their final patches in 2007, and it has not received any attention since, which casts a shadow on its asking price. Do not pay full price for this game. Instead, buy it as part a bundle or in a sale. It is a satisfying experience for the hardcore, and even casual shooter.Stone dumb AI amuses more often than frustrate, and once you learn their recognition patterns, you're nearly untouchable. All that said, this is a fun futuristic if somewhat thoughtfless romp.

Now that I have, boy, the graphics quality still doesn't show it's age. I play this on Normal setting but I felt like playing on Hard. The nano-suit energy battery drained really quick. The ammo is scarce. The enemies are everywhere. The stealth and tactical approach are broken. I tried going Predator when infiltrating an enemy base and the cloaking device auto-disabled before I even had a chance to do any stealth kill because the battery already drained. The sniper rifle doesn't have suppresor and really hard to aim enemy from far away, so tactical approach by cloaking and sniping almost always ended with direct combat. Second, although the game is a sandbox, you really don't have any reason to exploring the island. Third, some of the level are frustrating because the game doesn't give  clear explanation on what to do. The final mission for example, you have to survive swarm of enemies and kill the boss using a special gun, but no explanation given on how to use it (you can't just shoot it). So between shooting the swarm of enemies, salvaging ammo, dodging deadly flames and attacks, you have to figure out yourself how to use this new special gun and keep dying in the process. Really annoying.The story is mediocre, little bit boring for my taste. The multiplayer doesn't work anymore because the servers were closed in 2014. Overall, a really good and innovative game back in 2007, but for today, I suggest save your time and play newer games instead.CONCLUSION :Recommended on sale price.

Or hiting those tropical buildings smashing them into pieces, or driving like a crazy driver, or having a swim on a paradise beach while the sun was setting and some northkoreans were yelling strange things...**maximum nostalgia**Now, time for my subjective and totally parcial review. I can only give this game a 10/10 because what it meant at that time: -no one ever had done a similar gameplay concept before-the graphics were very advanced, and even today looks really nice-The crytek engine, it was mind-blowing. At that time, who could ever think that it would possible to have so much freedom in a game? that it would be possible to pick up random animals and throw them away or even use them as weapons?-The multiplayer, it put very well all that freedom into an online gameplay with a fair amount of players and very big maps-To sum up, it became a reference in no time after release. Everyone would use it as a reference when comparing graphics , when building a new PC, when comparing gameplay features.... And the famous words "NASA computer" became one of the most used for years thanks to this game. Can the NASA computers run it today with all settings at max? :P

												While Crysis' story was never really anything special to begin with, it certainly gets the job done. It takes some unexpected twists and turns along the way, and it does lead to a fairly interesting conclusion, but all in all it's clear that this is a game of gameplay over story. If you want something with a story that will rival franchises like Half-Life or Bioshock, you're looking in the wrong place. The story of all the Crysis games combined serves only one purpose, and that purpose is to give you a reason for going from A to B if wanderlust alone isn't going to cut it.Now then, how is the gameplay?The gameplay is great. It's everything you expect in a modern shooter - Decent-to-good AI, a nice selection of satisfying weaponry, explosives and gadgets. The Nano-Suit turns out to be one of the most interesting features in any FPS since the Gravity Gun, and the game is ripe for multiple playthroughs thanks to all of your options and the, at times, huge maps that you can get lost in. Crysis is perhaps the flagship of what a liniear open-world game can be - No, you're never really 'free' but you don't feel like you're being pushed through a bottleneck - because you're not! What Crysis likes to do is to give you a fairly simply objective, a huge map, and then basically leave it up to you as to how you go about completing your mission. You can go in guns blazing, blowing up enemies left, right and center, or you can play it like you would any stealth game, capitalizing on your ability to turn invisible. Graphically there's not really much to say. You can pick up and play this game today, and you won't be disappointed. Even by our current standards, this game arguably looks better than a lot of new releases. The low pricetag also means that it's going to outclass a lot of otherwise very competent indi-shooters. Definitely an all-time classic for me, and in my opinion the best game in the series.

												08-Aug-2016 :  Finished main storyEquipment : MSI GT80-2QE NotebookREVIEW :I never had a chance to play this game back in 2007 because I didn't have the hardware strong enough to run it. Now that I have, boy, the graphics quality still doesn't show it's age. Technically, I didn't have any problem running this with newer hardware in Windows 10 environment, but I have problems with the gameplay aspects. First, the difficulty. I play this on Normal setting but I felt like playing on Hard. The nano-suit energy battery drained really quick. The ammo is scarce. The enemies are everywhere. The stealth and tactical approach are broken. I tried going Predator when infiltrating an enemy base and the cloaking device auto-disabled before I even had a chance to do any stealth kill because the battery already drained. The sniper rifle doesn't have suppresor and really hard to aim enemy from far away, so tactical approach by cloaking and sniping almost always ended with direct combat. Second, although the game is a sandbox, you really don't have any reason to exploring the island. Third, some of the level are frustrating because the game doesn't give  clear explanation on what to do. The final mission for example, you have to survive swarm of enemies and kill the boss using a special gun, but no explanation given on how to use it (you can't just shoot it). So between shooting the swarm of enemies, salvaging ammo, dodging deadly flames and attacks, you have to figure out yourself how to use this new special gun and keep dying in the process. Really annoying.The story is mediocre, little bit boring for my taste. The multiplayer doesn't work anymore because the servers were closed in 2014. Overall, a really good and innovative game back in 2007, but for today, I suggest save your time and play newer games instead.CONCLUSION :Recommended on sale price.
